text:
One dimension I would consider here is persona.

If you're marketing to an end user (which you probably are if your ACV is less than 24k/year), it's likely going to be better to go with scrappy multi-media that's resonates. I would look for a content marketer who can use Canva, Descript, etc. to built what they need. It won't be as polished, but the CM will be really close to the message and able to quickly create things that resonate with the audience.

If you're marketing to a decision-maker (which you almost definitely are as your ACV goes over $50k) then that persona is going to expect a certain level of polish. They'll equate budget videos with an immature brand that isn't "enterprise ready".

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

elements.text:

If you're marketing to a decision-maker (which you almost definitely are as your ACV goes over $50k) then that persona is going to expect a certain level of polish. They'll equate budget videos with an immature brand that isn't "enterprise ready".

text:
I would second what <@U010GTFAFK9> said about hiring a senior role first.

If you can swing it, I also think it's best to hire dedicated designers and copy/content writers. There are some exceptions where this may not be the best approach, but if you have the funds for that kind of headcount, it's what I feel ensures the best results.

If you can find folks who can do other things in a pinch (ex: a writer who knows some design basics, a designer who can dabble in video, a videographer who can do a little animation), then that flexibility can be useful, especially if you're prioritizing speed and scrappiness. But specialists will generally produce the best results.

elements.text:

If you can find folks who can do other things in a pinch (ex: a writer who knows some design basics, a designer who can dabble in video, a videographer who can do a little animation), then that flexibility can be useful, especially if you're prioritizing speed and scrappiness. But specialists will generally produce the best results.

text:
For the content directors/managers out there:

Does your org use any data monitoring or dashboards to monitor the performance of the content you produce and publish? I’m asking from the POV of organic search.

What do you monitor beyond GSC (clicks, impressions, position, and CTA)? GA?

We’re experimenting with pipelining data into Data Studio to create our own content monitoring dashboards for client pages we publish and refresh.

Appreciate any ideas — I’m in the initial stages of riffing on what a content dashboard could do.

text:
Not currently, due to a ridiculous amount of silos and politics. But come hell or high water, we will have dashboards and reports that directly connect traffic sources to engagement and conversion down the funnel, all the way up to the impact on key biz objectives. We had it at Eventbrite and I’ve instructed all the startups I’ve advised to do it. 

What they look like and what they can do, will depend on what matters most to stakeholders. But the gist is that they’ll all demonstrate how traffic acquired leads to OKRs. 

I’m happy to grok this 1:1 if you want.

text: <@U01ANAZTZTK> is your brand identity baked out?  I've found is if you've got a strong brand identity mapped out (and somewhat dynamic), you can hire a mid-level (3-5 yrs) designer who'll be able to build on top of this guidance and build assets like the ones you mentioned, with ease. However, coming back to what <@U01AHL8AGBB> said, if you're looking for someone to ideate and conceptualize the connective tissue between your product and what audiences value the most from a visual standpoint, invest in a senior hire first.
